Message.Issue: As it is declared in your code, parameter 'idHook' of P/Invoke 'HookNativeMethods.CallNextHookEx(int, int, int, IntPtr)' will be 4 bytes wide on 64-bit platforms. This is not correct, as the actual native declaration of this API indicates it should be 8 bytes wide on 64-bit platforms. Consult the MSDN Platform SDK documentation for help determining what data type should be used instead of 'int'.

'KeyEventArgsExt.FromRawDataGlobal(int, IntPtr)' calls into 'Marshal.PtrToStructure(IntPtr, Type)' which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, 'Marshal.PtrToStructure(IntPtr, Type)' is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: ->'KeyEventArgsExt.FromRawDataGlobal(int, IntPtr)' ->'KeyEventArgsExt.FromRawDataGlobal(int, IntPtr)' ->'KeyEventArgsExt.FromRawData(int, IntPtr, bool)' ->'HotKeySetsListener.ProcessCallback(int, IntPtr)'

Rule.Name: COM visible type base types should be COM visible
Rule.Description: COM visible types should have an object hierarchy that is uniformly COM visible.
Rule.Resolution: {0} is marked ComVisible(true) but has the following ComVisible(false) types in its object hierarchy: {1}

Rule.Name: Do not indirectly expose methods with link demands
Rule.Description: Do not wrap a method protected by a LinkDemand with a method that does not perform a security check. A LinkDemand checks the permissions of the immediate caller rather than checking the permissions of all callers in the call stack. In this case, the permissions of the wrapper method will be checked. If the wrapper method does not, itself, check the permissions of callers higher in the call stack, malicious code might be able to execute the wrapped function even though it lacks permission to do so.
Rule.Resolution: {0} calls into {1} which has a LinkDemand. By making this call, {1} is indirectly exposed to user code. Review the following call stack that might expose a way to circumvent security protection: {2}

Rule.Name: P/Invoke declarations should be portable
Rule.Resolution: As it is declared in your code, parameter {0} of P/Invoke {1} will be {2} bytes wide on {3} platforms. This is not correct, as the actual native declaration of this API indicates it should be {4} bytes wide on {3} platforms. Consult the MSDN Platform SDK documentation for help determining what data type should be used instead of {5}.

As it is declared in your code, the return type of P/Invoke {0} will be {1} bytes wide on {2} platforms. This is not correct, as the actual native declaration of this API indicates it should be {3} bytes wide on {2} platforms. Consult the MSDN Platform SDK documentation for help determining what data type should be used instead of {4}.
